description: From Middle English scuttel, scutel, from Old English scutel (‚Äúdish, platter‚Äù), from Latin scutella, diminutive form of Latin scutra (‚Äúflat tray, dish‚Äù), perhaps related to Latin scutum (‚Äúshield‚Äù); compare Dutch schotel and German Sch√ºssel.

entries.meaning: A container like an open bucket (usually to hold and carry coal).
(obsolete, Northern England and Scotland) A dish, platter or a trencher.

description: Borrowed from Middle French escoutille (compare French √©coutille), from Old Norse skaut (‚Äúcorner of a cloth, of a sail‚Äù), or alternatively from Spanish escotilla, ultimately from Gothic êçÉêå∫êå∞êåøêçÑêçÉ (skauts, ‚Äúprojecting edge, fringe‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *skautaz (‚Äúcorner; wedge; lap‚Äù). Compare German Scho√ü, Old English sƒãƒìat. More at sheet.

entries.meaning: A small hatch or opening in a boat. Also, small opening in a boat or ship for draining water from open deck.
(construction) A hatch that provides access to the roof from the interior of a building.

verbs.description: scuttle (third-person singular simple present scuttles, present participle scuttling, simple past and past participle scuttled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To cut a hole or holes through the bottom, deck, or sides of (as of a ship), for any purpose.
(transitive) To deliberately sink one's ship or boat by any means, usually by order of the vessel's commander or owner.
examples: The Vichy French fleet in Toulon in 1942 scuttled itself as a final "fuck you" to the invading Germans.

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension) To deliberately wreck one's vehicle (of any sort).
(transitive, by extension) To undermine or thwart oneself or one's position or property, especially deliberately.
examples: The candidate had scuttled his chances with his unhinged outburst.

entries.meaning: A quick pace; a short run.

verbs.description: scuttle (third-person singular simple present scuttles, present participle scuttling, simple past and past participle scuttled)
